newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.

text.p: HOWARD SAYS HANSON RACE ISSUE WILL FADE AWAY
Prime Minister, John Howard, has denied reports of disquiet within the Coalition about his approach to the debate on race and immigration.
The Anglican Bishop for Canberra and Goulburn, Bishop George Browning, has said Liberals have expressed dissatisfaction to him about the Prime Minister's handling of the debate.
But Mr Howard has told the Coalition party room the suggestion is totally false.
He says he's sure, and has been convinced by his colleagues, his attitude to the debate is right.
Mr Howard has also expressed a belief the debate will die out, likening it to a meteorite which sails through the firmament and then disappears.
VARIETY IS SPICE OF LIFE IN QUARANTINE SERVICE
Melbourne Cup starter, Oscar Schindler, and two bongo antelopes were among the most unusual animals the Quarantine service approved for entry to Australia in October.
The service seized a half-metre long python found in an international aircraft in Adelaide, a pig's ear found in baggage and a dried bull's penis mailed to a woman from overseas.
In its October report, the Quarantine Service says it also dealt with a cricket which had caused havoc by attaching itself to a passenger's head during an international flight to Sydney.

The service took a range of court action, including against a student who was fined nearly 15-hundred dollars for importing fruit, meat and eggs and a manager fined the same amount for illegally importing mangoes in an airline carry-on bag.
CALLS FOR INVESTIGATION INTO TOWNSVILLE ATTACK
In north Queensland, Townsville Mayor Tony Mooney has called on police to investigate allegations an Aboriginal Police Liaison Officer watched while two Japanese students were assaulted.
Councillor Mooney says the weekend incident was captured on a security camera, now being examined by police.
He says after the assault, the attacker gave what appears to be a High Five salute to a nearby Police Liaison Officer.
Councillor Mooney says that's disgraceful behaviour given PLOs are there to ensure safety, to liaise with the community and make a safer public environment.
CALL FOR STAY OF PROCEEDINS FOR GARIBALDI DEFENDANT
A former director of Garibaldi Smallgoods has asked the Supreme Court in Adelaide to put-off a manslaughter charge against him because he can't afford legal representation.
Neville Mead, who was financial controller of the now-defunct company, is applying for a stay of proceedings.
He says the charge is too serious for him to represent himself,

He's too poor to pay lawyers and has been refused legal aid. Neville Mead is jointly charged with Luciano and Philip Marchi over the death of four-year-old Nikki Robinson ... who died in a contaminated mettwurst epidemic last year.
NSW OPPOSITION LEADER WANTS TRUTH ABOUT YELDHAM
The New South Wales Opposition has called on the Police Royal Commission to release details of its inquiries into Justice David Yeldham after his suicide yesterday.
The call echoes that of Labor M-P Franca Arena, who raised questions in Parliament about the Commission's investigations into the judge before his death.

Mrs Arena's remained strident in her calls for the Royal Commission to reveal what, if anything, its inquiries turned up. Opposition Leader, Peter Collins, says Mrs Arena was guilty of a dreadful abuse of Parliamentary privilege in naming Justice Yeldham.
But Mr Collins says the Royal Commission must now reveal the results of its investigation of Justice Yeldham, for the sake of his family.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
